variant.question: In relation to the wind speed and direction at the top of the friction layer, which change in wind will a pilot normally experience during descent to the surface over land in the northern hemisphere?

options.text: Backing ca. 10 degrees, speed is reduced by ca. 30%.
Backing ca. 30 degrees, speed is reduced by ca. 50%.
Veering ca. 10 degrees, speed is reduced by ca. 30%.
Veering ca. 30 degrees, speed is reduced by ca. 50%.

variant.question: The height of the friction layer is the largest under the following conditions:

options.text: Rough terrain, high wind speed, unstable air, during a warm summer afternoon.
Rough terrain, high wind speed, unstable air, during a warm summer morning.
Flat terrain, high wind speed, stable air, during a warm summer morning.
Flat terrain, low wind speed, unstable air, during a warm summer afternoon.

variant.question: You are on an approach to an airfield, descending through the friction layer. The wind changes from a headwind to a slight right crosswind.

options.text: The airfield is most probably situated near water (on the seaside).
This is due to changing wind directions on approach
This is typical for northern hemisphere.
This is typical for southern hemisphere.

options.text: Convective turbulence.
Turbulence induced by wind speed.
Orographic turbulence.

variant.question: The vertical extent of the friction layer depends primarily on..

options.text: wind speed, roughness of surface, and temperature.
roughness of surface, temperature, and local time.
temperature, local time, and environmental lapse rate.
stability, wind speed, and roughness of surface.

variant.question: For an inland aerodrome, how does the vertical extent of the friction layer and amount of turbulence in this layer change in the late afternoon in midsummer, compared to the same time in winter (assuming similar surface wind conditions)?

options.text: Decrease in both vertical extent and turbulence.
Increase in both vertical extent and turbulence.
Decrease in vertical extent and increase in turbulence.
Increase in vertical extent and decrease in turbulence.

variant.question: In the Northern Hemisphere, when flying west, an aircraft experiences a head wind. Which of the following statements is correct?

backing of the wind and decrease of wind speed at the surface.
backing of the wind and increase of wind speed at the surface.
